case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 565 and 1470 to 1474 of 1970

facts.text: Six appeals by certificate from Patna High Court judgment dated 7 November 1969.

anchor.surface_text: gment dated 7 November, 1969 of the High Court at Patna quashing the order of the Government of India dated 20 September, 1967, and directing that the respondents must companytinue to hold rank as assigned to them in 1958.

facts.text: Patna High Court quashed Government of India order dated 20 September 1967 and directed promotees continue to hold year of allotment as in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Patna quashing the order of the Government of India dated 20 September, 1967, and directing that the respondents must companytinue to hold rank as assigned to them in 1958. The appellants and the respondents are number members of the Indian Administrative Service.

facts.text: Appellants are direct recruits appointed to IAS in 1949 and 1950 via competitive examination.

anchor.surface_text: The direct recruits were appointed to the Indian Administrative Service in the years 1949 and 1950 as a result of companypetitive examination held for recruitment of candidates to that Service.

facts.text: Respondents are promotees initially recruited to Bihar State Civil Service and promoted to IAS in 1955 and 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The promotees were initially recruited to the executive branch of the Bihar State Civil Service and were subsequently in the years 1955 and 1956 promoted to the Indian Administrative Service.

facts.text: Government of India on 3 September 1958 allotted promotees year 1948, placed below junior most direct recruit of 1948 allotment.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India on 3 September, 1958 allotted to the promotees the year 1948 and placed them below the junior most amongst the direct recruits of the 1948 allotment.

facts.text: Direct recruits made representations against 1958 Government of India decision.

anchor.surface_text: The direct recruits thereafter made representation against the decision of the Government of India.

facts.text: State of Bihar forwarded direct recruits' representation to Government of India on 13 January 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, on 13 January, 1965 the State of Bihar forwarded the. representation of the direct recruits to the Government of India against the decision made by the Government of India in the year 1958.

facts.text: Government of India tentative decision on 4 January 1966 to allow direct recruits' representation due to wrong facts and interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: On 4 January. 1966 the Government of India took a tentative decision to allow the representation of the direct recruits on the ground that the previous decision was on wrong facts and on wrong interpretation.

facts.text: State of Bihar represented to Government of India on 14 April 1967 to reject direct recruits' representation alleging wrong facts.

anchor.surface_text: On 14 April, 1967 the State of Bihar represented to the Government of India to reject the representation of the direct recruits on the ground that the facts alleged by the direct recruits were wrong.

facts.text: Government of India on 20 September 1967 allowed direct recruits' representation, revised promotees' seniority to 1950 or 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On 20 September, 1967 the Government of India however allowed the representation of the direct recruits and revised the seniority of the promotees and allotted to some of the promotees the year 1950 and to some of the promotees the year 1952

facts.text: Promotees challenged Government of India memorandum dated 20 September 1967 in Patna High Court principally on ground that GOI wrong on retrospective declaration competence.

anchor.surface_text: The promotees impeached the Government of India Memorandum dated 20 September, 1967 principally on the ground that the Government of India-was wrong in holding that it was number companypetent to the State of Bihar to make a retrospective declaration

facts.text: Patna High Court allowed promotees' challenge, quashed 20 September 1967 order, directed continue 1958 allotment.

anchor.surface_text: The promotees succeeded in the High Court. The High Court quashed the order dated 20 September, 1967 and directed that the promotees would companytinue to hold the year of allotment assigned to them in the year 1958.

facts.text: Indian Administrative Service constituted under Memorandum of Agreement dated 21 October 1946 between Government of India and Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: The origin of the Indian Administrative Service is to be found in the Memorandum of Agreement dated 21 October, 1946 between the Government of India and the Government of the then Provinces. The Indian Administrative Service came to be companystituted

facts.text: For Bihar cadre, 144 senior posts: 103 state, 41 central; 36 by promotion, 108 direct.

anchor.surface_text: For the State of Bihar there are 8 items. The first item relates to senior posts under the State Government which are 103 in number and item 2 relates to senior posits under the Central Government which are 41 in number. Of these 144 posts 36 are to be filled by promotion

facts.text: Total authorized strength Bihar cadre 211 posts: 175 direct, 36 promotion.

anchor.surface_text: Of the total authorized strength of 211 cadre posts in the State of Bihar 175 are direct recruitment posts and 36 are promotion posts.

facts.text: Promotees promoted in 1955-1956 after commencement of relevant rules.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals relate to promotees after the abovementioned Rules and Regulations came into existence. The question of seniority of promotees vis-a-vis direct recruits is companyered by rule 3 3  b  of the Indian Administrative Service  Regulation of Seniority

facts.text: Chief Secretary Bihar letter 9 April 1958 to GOI could not amount to declaration of equivalent posts per direct recruits.

facts.text: Ad hoc list prepared 28 December 1954, select list 26 December 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds State Government has power to make retrospective declaration of posts equivalent to senior posts.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons, we uphold the judgment of the High Court that the memorandum dated 20 September, 1967 which stated that the State Government companyld number retrospectively declare a post to be equivalent to a senior post was bad.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court direction that promotees continue 1958 ranks, as year of allotment needs Central Government approval in consultation with UPSC.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however further directed that the promotees must companytinue to hold ranks as assigned to them in the year 1958 This order of the High Court is to be set aside, for the reason that the year of allotment will number have to be determined

facts.text: Appeals dismissed insofar as quashing GOI order 20 Sep 1967, allowed re setting aside HC 1958 direction.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are therefore dismissed in so far as they relate to quashing of the order of the Central Government dated 20 September, 1967. The appeals are allowed setting aside the order of the High Court that the promotees would companytinue

facts.text: Definition of senior post changed in 1967 by notification dated 17 April 1967 effective 22 April 1967; appeals governed by prior definition.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that the definition of. senior post underwent change in the year 1967 by numberification No. 27/47/64-AIS III -A dated 17 April, 1967 and the new definition of senior post came into effect on 22 April, 1967.

facts.text: Deputy Secretary GOI letter 3 September 1958 accepted State recommendations, allotted 1948 year.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Secretary to the Government of India by letter dated 3 September, 1958 accepted the recommendation of the State Government with regard to the promotees and allotted to them the year 1948 and placed the promotees below Shri B. S. Srivastava

Appeals from the judgment and order dated November 7, 1969 of the Patna High Court in Civil Writ Jurisdiction Cases Nos. 853, 854 and 877 to 880 of 1968.

issues.text: The controversy in the present appeals is as to the seniority between the direct recruits and the promotees under the Indian Administrative Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1954

anchor.surface_text: The controversy in the present appeals is as to the seniority between the direct recruits and the promotees under the Indian Administrative Service Regulation of Seniority Rules, 1954. The Government of India on 3 September, 1958 allotted to the promotees the year 1948 and placed them below the junior most amongst the direct recruits of the 1948 allotment.

issues.text: the question of the year of allotment of the promotees who were promoted to the Service, after the commencement of the Rules, in the years 1955 and 1956

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals raise the question of the year of allotment of the promotees who were promoted to the Service, after the commencement of the Rules, in the years 1955 and 1956. Therefore, rule 3 3 b applies to the case of the promotees vis-a-vis the direct recruits.

issues.text: whether the Central Government gave any approval in consultation with the Union Public Service Commission within the meaning of rule 3 3 b so as to enable the promotees the benefit of the period of officiation prior to the date of the inclusion of their names in the select list

anchor.surface_text: On the materials in the present appeals we are unable to hold that the Central Government gave any approval in consultation with the Union Public Service Commission within the meaning of rule 3 3 b so as to enable the promotees the benefit of the period of officiation prior to the date of the inclusion of their names in the select list.

issues.text: whether it is open to the State to make a retrospective declaration with regard to posts being made equivalent to senior posts

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the direct recruits that it is not open to the State to make a retrospective declaration with regard to posts being made equivalent to senior posts is unacceptable. From the point of view of workability of the rule as well as the circumstances and the conditions of service it may not always be practicable to make such prospective declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Materials on record do not show specific approval by Central Government in consultation with UPSC for pre-select list officiation period as required by second proviso to rule 3(3)(b).

holdings.text: The contention on behalf of the direct recruits that it is not open to the State to make a retrospective declaration with regard to posts being made equivalent to senior posts is unacceptable.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the direct recruits that it is not open to the State to make a retrospective declaration with regard to posts being made equivalent to senior posts is unacceptable. From the point of view of workability of the rule as well as the circumstances and the conditions of service it may not always be practicable to make such prospective declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Workability of rule, service conditions, and policy to balance direct recruits and promotees require permitting retrospective declarations; prospective only would defeat purpose.

holdings.text: The harmonious construction of the definition of senior post occurring in the 1954 Cadre Rules along with rule 3(3)(b) of the Regulation of Seniority Rules is that promotee will by a legal fiction obtain advantage of the period of officiation first by the declaration and second by the approval of the Central Government in consultation with the Union Public Service Commission.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition of senior post read with rule 3(3)(b) permits retrospective declaration by State followed by Central/UPSC approval to deem pre-select officiation via legal fiction.

holdings.text: For these reasons, we uphold the judgment of the High Court that the memorandum dated 20 September, 1967 which stated that the State Government could not retrospectively declare a post to be equivalent to a senior post was bad. The State Government has power to make such a retrospective declaration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior reasoning on workability, scheme of rules, and harmonious construction confirm State power for retrospective declaration; GOI erred in denying it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1958 allotment lacked required approval under rule 3(3)(b) second proviso; year of allotment must be freshly determined following proper procedure.

holdings.text: The appeals are therefore dismissed in so far as they relate to quashing of the order of the Central Government dated 20 September, 1967. precedents.case_name: R. Nim, I.P.S. v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: effect of the second proviso to rule 3(3)(b): limits operation of first proviso by dividing officiating period into pre- and post-inclusion in Select List; pre-inclusion period countable only if approved by Central Government in consultation with UPSC
precedents.cited_holding: The second proviso limits the operation of the first proviso by dividing the officiating period into two classes first, a period before the date of inclusion of an officer in the Select List and, secondly, the period after that date. The first period can only be counted if such period is approved by the Central Government in consultation with the Union Public Service Commission.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the direct recruits that it is not open to the State to make a retrospective declaration with regard to posts being made equivalent to senior posts is unacceptable. From the point of view of workability of the rule as well as the circumstances and the conditions of service it may not always be practicable to make such prospective declaration.

The appeals are therefore dismissed in so far as they relate to quashing of the order of the Central Government dated 20 September, 1967. The appeals are allowed setting aside the order of the High Court that the promotees would continue to hold ranks as assigned to them in the year 1958.
